key_points: Donald Trump's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and his support for conspiracy theories are cited as reasons for his loss in the last election.
Trump suggested, without evidence, his political enemies were part of a satanic pedophile cult.
During a live town hall with NBC's Savannah Guthrie, Trump was asked to disavow the QAnon conspiracy theory.
QAnon believers think a cabal of Democrats and celebrities run a child-sex-trafficking ring plotting against Trump.
Trump claimed ignorance about QAnon but acknowledged the group's stance against pedophilia, contradicting his prior statement.
Trump criticized antifa and the radical left for their alleged violence and destruction.
Despite losing the election, QAnon supporters continued to promote theories about Trump being reinstated as president.
A theory emerged among QAnon followers that John F. Kennedy Jr., who died in 1999, would appear in Texas and possibly run with Trump in 2024.
The conspiracy theories embraced by Trump and his followers are outlined as disconnected from reality.
QAnon's unwavering support for Trump persists despite numerous disproven claims and theories.
spokespersons: Donald Trump (Former President of the United States)
